diagrams.description: Computer Vision encompasses algorithms, architectures, tasks, and applications enabling machines to perceive and understand visual information. Core algorithms include edge detection using Canny or Sobel operators identifying boundaries, feature matching comparing image regions using SIFT or ORB descriptors, optical flow tracking motion between frames, and structure from motion reconstructing 3D scenes. Neural network architectures employ convolutional neural networks as fundamental building blocks, ResNet with skip connections enabling deeper networks, VGG providing systematic depth exploration, Inception using multi-scale processing, YOLO for real-time object detection, and vision transformers applying attention mechanisms. Computer vision tasks span image classification categorizing entire images, object detection locating multiple objects with bounding boxes, semantic segmentation labeling every pixel by class, instance segmentation distinguishing individual objects, pose estimation detecting human body keypoints, facial recognition identifying individuals, and optical character recognition extracting text. Applications include autonomous vehicles perceiving roads and obstacles, medical imaging diagnosing diseases from X-rays and MRIs, surveillance systems monitoring security, robotics enabling manipulation and navigation, augmented reality overlaying digital content, quality inspection detecting manufacturing defects, and agricultural monitoring assessing crop health. Challenges address occlusion handling partially visible objects, illumination variations managing lighting changes, viewpoint invariance recognizing objects from different angles, and real-time processing achieving low latency.
